## Description {#details}

This file is a part of <a href="/docs/api/classes/anonymous-namespace-memorysanitizer-cpp-/memorysanitizer">MemorySanitizer</a>, a detector of uninitialized reads.

The algorithm of the tool is similar to Memcheck (<a href="https://static.usenix.org/event/usenix05/tech/general/full_papers/seward/seward_html/usenix2005.html">https://static.usenix.org/event/usenix05/tech/general/full&#95;papers/seward/seward&#95;html/usenix2005.html</a>) We associate a few shadow bits with every byte of the application memory, poison the shadow of the malloc-ed or alloca-ed memory, load the shadow, bits on every memory read, propagate the shadow bits through some of the arithmetic instruction (including MOV), store the shadow bits on every memory write, report a bug on some other instructions (e.g. JMP) if the associated shadow is poisoned.

But there are differences too. The first and the major one: compiler instrumentation instead of binary instrumentation. This gives us much better register allocation, possible compiler optimizations and a fast start-up. But this brings the major issue as well: msan needs to see all program events, including system calls and reads/writes in system libraries, so we either need to compile <em>everything</em> with msan or use a binary translation component (e.g. DynamoRIO) to instrument pre-built libraries. Another difference from Memcheck is that we use 8 shadow bits per byte of application memory and use a direct shadow mapping. This greatly simplifies the instrumentation code and avoids races on shadow updates (Memcheck is single-threaded so races are not a concern there. Memcheck uses 2 shadow bits per byte with a slow path storage that uses 8 bits per byte).

The default value of shadow is 0, which means &quot;clean&quot; (not poisoned).

Every module initializer should call &#95;&#95;msan&#95;init to ensure that the shadow memory is ready. On error, &#95;&#95;msan&#95;warning is called. Since parameters and return values may be passed via registers, we have a specialized thread-local shadow for return values (&#95;&#95;msan&#95;retval&#95;tls) and parameters (&#95;&#95;msan&#95;param&#95;tls). 

<CodeBlock>
                      Origin tracking.
</CodeBlock>

<a href="/docs/api/classes/anonymous-namespace-memorysanitizer-cpp-/memorysanitizer">MemorySanitizer</a> can track origins (allocation points) of all uninitialized values. This behavior is controlled with a flag (msan-track-origins) and is disabled by default.

Origins are 4-byte values created and interpreted by the runtime library. They are stored in a second shadow mapping, one 4-byte value for 4 bytes of application memory. Propagation of origins is basically a bunch of &quot;select&quot; instructions that pick the origin of a dirty argument, if an instruction has one.

Every 4 aligned, consecutive bytes of application memory have one origin value associated with them. If these bytes contain uninitialized data coming from 2 different allocations, the last store wins. Because of this, <a href="/docs/api/classes/anonymous-namespace-memorysanitizer-cpp-/memorysanitizer">MemorySanitizer</a> reports can show unrelated origins, but this is unlikely in practice.

Origins are meaningless for fully initialized values, so <a href="/docs/api/classes/anonymous-namespace-memorysanitizer-cpp-/memorysanitizer">MemorySanitizer</a> avoids storing origin to memory when a fully initialized value is stored. This way it avoids needless overwriting origin of the 4-byte region on a short (i.e. 1 byte) clean store, and it is also good for performance. 

<CodeBlock>
                       Atomic handling.
</CodeBlock>

Ideally, every atomic store of application value should update the corresponding shadow location in an atomic way. Unfortunately, atomic store of two disjoint locations can not be done without severe slowdown.

Therefore, we implement an approximation that may err on the safe side. In this implementation, every atomically accessed location in the program may only change from (partially) uninitialized to fully initialized, but not the other way around. We load the shadow <em>after</em> the application load, and we store the shadow <em>before</em> the app store. Also, we always store clean shadow (if the application store is atomic). This way, if the store-load pair constitutes a happens-before arc, shadow store and load are correctly ordered such that the load will get either the value that was stored, or some later value (which is always clean).

This does not work very well with Compare-And-Swap (CAS) and Read-Modify-Write (RMW) operations. To follow the above logic, CAS and RMW must store the new shadow before the app operation, and load the shadow after the app operation. Computers don&#39;t work this way. Current implementation ignores the load aspect of CAS/RMW, always returning a clean value. It implements the store part as a simple atomic store by storing a clean shadow. 

<CodeBlock>
                 Instrumenting inline assembly.
</CodeBlock>

For inline assembly code LLVM has little idea about which memory locations become initialized depending on the arguments. It can be possible to figure out which arguments are meant to point to inputs and outputs, but the actual semantics can be only visible at runtime. In the Linux kernel it&#39;s also possible that the arguments only indicate the offset for a base taken from a segment register, so it&#39;s dangerous to treat any asm() arguments as pointers. We take a conservative approach generating calls to &#95;&#95;msan&#95;instrument&#95;asm&#95;store(ptr, size) , which defer the memory unpoisoning to the runtime library. The latter can perform more complex address checks to figure out whether it&#39;s safe to touch the shadow memory. Like with atomic operations, we call &#95;&#95;msan&#95;instrument&#95;asm&#95;store() before the assembly call, so that changes to the shadow memory will be seen by other threads together with main memory initialization. 

<CodeBlock>
             KernelMemorySanitizer (KMSAN) implementation.
</CodeBlock>

The major differences between KMSAN and MSan instrumentation are:
<ul>
<li>KMSAN always tracks the origins and implies msan-keep-going=true;</li>
<li>KMSAN allocates shadow and origin memory for each page separately, so there are no explicit accesses to shadow and origin in the instrumentation. Shadow and origin values for a particular X-byte memory location (X=1,2,4,8) are accessed through pointers obtained via the &#95;&#95;msan&#95;metadata&#95;ptr&#95;for&#95;load&#95;X(ptr) &#95;&#95;msan&#95;metadata&#95;ptr&#95;for&#95;store&#95;X(ptr) functions. The corresponding functions check that the X-byte accesses are possible and returns the pointers to shadow and origin memory. Arbitrary sized accesses are handled with: &#95;&#95;msan&#95;metadata&#95;ptr&#95;for&#95;load&#95;n(ptr, size) &#95;&#95;msan&#95;metadata&#95;ptr&#95;for&#95;store&#95;n(ptr, size); Note that the sanitizer code has to deal with how shadow/origin pairs returned by the these functions are represented in different ABIs. In the X86&#95;64 ABI they are returned in RDX:RAX, in PowerPC64 they are returned in r3 and r4, and in the <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/systemz">SystemZ</a> ABI they are written to memory pointed to by a hidden parameter.</li>
<li>TLS variables are stored in a single per-task struct. A call to a function &#95;&#95;msan&#95;get&#95;context&#95;state() returning a pointer to that struct is inserted into every instrumented function before the entry block;</li>
<li>&#95;&#95;msan&#95;warning() takes a 32-bit origin parameter;</li>
<li>local variables are poisoned with &#95;&#95;msan&#95;poison&#95;alloca() upon function entry and unpoisoned with &#95;&#95;msan&#95;unpoison&#95;alloca() before leaving the function;</li>
<li>the pass doesn&#39;t declare any global variables or add global constructors to the translation unit.</li>
</ul>


Also, KMSAN currently ignores uninitialized memory passed into inline asm calls, making sure we&#39;re on the safe side wrt. possible false positives.

KernelMemorySanitizer only supports X86&#95;64, <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/systemz">SystemZ</a> and PowerPC64 at the moment.

<ProgramListing>

<Link id="l00001" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1"><Highlight kind="comment">//===- MemorySanitizer.cpp - detector of uninitialized reads --------------===//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00002" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00003" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Part of the LLVM Project, under the Apache License v2.0 with LLVM Exceptions.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00004" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// See https://llvm.org/LICENSE.txt for license information.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00005" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0 WITH LLVM-exception</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00006" /><CodeLine lineNumber="6"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00007" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//===----------------------------------------------------------------------===//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00008" /><CodeLine lineNumber="8"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00009" /><CodeLine lineNumber="9"><Highlight kind="comment">/// \\file</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00010" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10"><Highlight kind="comment">/// This file is a part of MemorySanitizer, a detector of uninitialized</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00011" /><CodeLine lineNumber="11"><Highlight kind="comment">/// reads.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00012" /><CodeLine lineNumber="12"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00013" /><CodeLine lineNumber="13"><Highlight kind="comment">/// The algorithm of the tool is similar to Memcheck</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00014" /><CodeLine lineNumber="14"><Highlight kind="comment">/// (https://static.usenix.org/event/usenix05/tech/general/full&#95;papers/seward/seward&#95;html/usenix2005.html)</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00015" /><CodeLine lineNumber="15"><Highlight kind="comment">/// We associate a few shadow bits with every byte of the application memory,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00016" /><CodeLine lineNumber="16"><Highlight kind="comment">/// poison the shadow of the malloc-ed or alloca-ed memory, load the shadow,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00017" /><CodeLine lineNumber="17"><Highlight kind="comment">/// bits on every memory read, propagate the shadow bits through some of the</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00018" /><CodeLine lineNumber="18"><Highlight kind="comment">/// arithmetic instruction (including MOV), store the shadow bits on every</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00019" /><CodeLine lineNumber="19"><Highlight kind="comment">/// memory write, report a bug on some other instructions (e.g. JMP) if the</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00020" /><CodeLine lineNumber="20"><Highlight kind="comment">/// associated shadow is poisoned.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00021" /><CodeLine lineNumber="21"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00022" /><CodeLine lineNumber="22"><Highlight kind="comment">/// But there are differences too. The first and the major one:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00023" /><CodeLine lineNumber="23"><Highlight kind="comment">/// compiler instrumentation instead of binary instrumentation. This</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00024" /><CodeLine lineNumber="24"><Highlight kind="comment">/// gives us much better register allocation, possible compiler</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00025" /><CodeLine lineNumber="25"><Highlight kind="comment">/// optimizations and a fast start-up. But this brings the major issue</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00026" /><CodeLine lineNumber="26"><Highlight kind="comment">/// as well: msan needs to see all program events, including system</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00027" /><CodeLine lineNumber="27"><Highlight kind="comment">/// calls and reads/writes in system libraries, so we either need to</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00028" /><CodeLine lineNumber="28"><Highlight kind="comment">/// compile &#42;everything&#42; with msan or use a binary translation</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00029" /><CodeLine lineNumber="29"><Highlight kind="comment">/// component (e.g. DynamoRIO) to instrument pre-built libraries.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00030" /><CodeLine lineNumber="30"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Another difference from Memcheck is that we use 8 shadow bits per</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00031" /><CodeLine lineNumber="31"><Highlight kind="comment">/// byte of application memory and use a direct shadow mapping. This</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00032" /><CodeLine lineNumber="32"><Highlight kind="comment">/// greatly simplifies the instrumentation code and avoids races on</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00033" /><CodeLine lineNumber="33"><Highlight kind="comment">/// shadow updates (Memcheck is single-threaded so races are not a</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00034" /><CodeLine lineNumber="34"><Highlight kind="comment">/// concern there. Memcheck uses 2 shadow bits per byte with a slow</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00035" /><CodeLine lineNumber="35"><Highlight kind="comment">/// path storage that uses 8 bits per byte).</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00036" /><CodeLine lineNumber="36"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00037" /><CodeLine lineNumber="37"><Highlight kind="comment">/// The default value of shadow is 0, which means &quot;clean&quot; (not poisoned).</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00038" /><CodeLine lineNumber="38"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00039" /><CodeLine lineNumber="39"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Every module initializer should call &#95;&#95;msan&#95;init to ensure that the</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00040" /><CodeLine lineNumber="40"><Highlight kind="comment">/// shadow memory is ready. On error, &#95;&#95;msan&#95;warning is called. Since</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00041" /><CodeLine lineNumber="41"><Highlight kind="comment">/// parameters and return values may be passed via registers, we have a</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00042" /><CodeLine lineNumber="42"><Highlight kind="comment">/// specialized thread-local shadow for return values</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00043" /><CodeLine lineNumber="43"><Highlight kind="comment">/// (&#95;&#95;msan&#95;retval&#95;tls) and parameters (&#95;&#95;msan&#95;param&#95;tls).</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00044" /><CodeLine lineNumber="44"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00045" /><CodeLine lineNumber="45"><Highlight kind="comment">///                           Origin tracking.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00046" /><CodeLine lineNumber="46"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00047" /><CodeLine lineNumber="47"><Highlight kind="comment">/// MemorySanitizer can track origins (allocation points) of all uninitialized</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00048" /><CodeLine lineNumber="48"><Highlight kind="comment">/// values. This behavior is controlled with a flag (msan-track-origins) and is</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00049" /><CodeLine lineNumber="49"><Highlight kind="comment">/// disabled by default.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00050" /><CodeLine lineNumber="50"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00051" /><CodeLine lineNumber="51"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Origins are 4-byte values created and interpreted by the runtime library.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00052" /><CodeLine lineNumber="52"><Highlight kind="comment">/// They are stored in a second shadow mapping, one 4-byte value for 4 bytes</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00053" /><CodeLine lineNumber="53"><Highlight kind="comment">/// of application memory. Propagation of origins is basically a bunch of</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00054" /><CodeLine lineNumber="54"><Highlight kind="comment">/// &quot;select&quot; instructions that pick the origin of a dirty argument, if an</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00055" /><CodeLine lineNumber="55"><Highlight kind="comment">/// instruction has one.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00056" /><CodeLine lineNumber="56"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00057" /><CodeLine lineNumber="57"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Every 4 aligned, consecutive bytes of application memory have one origin</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00058" /><CodeLine lineNumber="58"><Highlight kind="comment">/// value associated with them. If these bytes contain uninitialized data</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00059" /><CodeLine lineNumber="59"><Highlight kind="comment">/// coming from 2 different allocations, the last store wins. Because of this,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00060" /><CodeLine lineNumber="60"><Highlight kind="comment">/// MemorySanitizer reports can show unrelated origins, but this is unlikely in</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00061" /><CodeLine lineNumber="61"><Highlight kind="comment">/// practice.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00062" /><CodeLine lineNumber="62"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00063" /><CodeLine lineNumber="63"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Origins are meaningless for fully initialized values, so MemorySanitizer</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00064" /><CodeLine lineNumber="64"><Highlight kind="comment">/// avoids storing origin to memory when a fully initialized value is stored.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00065" /><CodeLine lineNumber="65"><Highlight kind="comment">/// This way it avoids needless overwriting origin of the 4-byte region on</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00066" /><CodeLine lineNumber="66"><Highlight kind="comment">/// a short (i.e. 1 byte) clean store, and it is also good for performance.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00067" /><CodeLine lineNumber="67"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00068" /><CodeLine lineNumber="68"><Highlight kind="comment">///                            Atomic handling.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00069" /><CodeLine lineNumber="69"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00070" /><CodeLine lineNumber="70"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Ideally, every atomic store of application value should update the</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00071" /><CodeLine lineNumber="71"><Highlight kind="comment">/// corresponding shadow location in an atomic way. Unfortunately, atomic store</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00072" /><CodeLine lineNumber="72"><Highlight kind="comment">/// of two disjoint locations can not be done without severe slowdown.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00073" /><CodeLine lineNumber="73"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00074" /><CodeLine lineNumber="74"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Therefore, we implement an approximation that may err on the safe side.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00075" /><CodeLine lineNumber="75"><Highlight kind="comment">/// In this implementation, every atomically accessed location in the program</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00076" /><CodeLine lineNumber="76"><Highlight kind="comment">/// may only change from (partially) uninitialized to fully initialized, but</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00077" /><CodeLine lineNumber="77"><Highlight kind="comment">/// not the other way around. We load the shadow &#95;after&#95; the application load,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00078" /><CodeLine lineNumber="78"><Highlight kind="comment">/// and we store the shadow &#95;before&#95; the app store. Also, we always store clean</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00079" /><CodeLine lineNumber="79"><Highlight kind="comment">/// shadow (if the application store is atomic). This way, if the store-load</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00080" /><CodeLine lineNumber="80"><Highlight kind="comment">/// pair constitutes a happens-before arc, shadow store and load are correctly</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00081" /><CodeLine lineNumber="81"><Highlight kind="comment">/// ordered such that the load will get either the value that was stored, or</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00082" /><CodeLine lineNumber="82"><Highlight kind="comment">/// some later value (which is always clean).</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00083" /><CodeLine lineNumber="83"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00084" /><CodeLine lineNumber="84"><Highlight kind="comment">/// This does not work very well with Compare-And-Swap (CAS) and</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00085" /><CodeLine lineNumber="85"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Read-Modify-Write (RMW) operations. To follow the above logic, CAS and RMW</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00086" /><CodeLine lineNumber="86"><Highlight kind="comment">/// must store the new shadow before the app operation, and load the shadow</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00087" /><CodeLine lineNumber="87"><Highlight kind="comment">/// after the app operation. Computers don&#39;t work this way. Current</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00088" /><CodeLine lineNumber="88"><Highlight kind="comment">/// implementation ignores the load aspect of CAS/RMW, always returning a clean</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00089" /><CodeLine lineNumber="89"><Highlight kind="comment">/// value. It implements the store part as a simple atomic store by storing a</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00090" /><CodeLine lineNumber="90"><Highlight kind="comment">/// clean shadow.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00091" /><CodeLine lineNumber="91"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00092" /><CodeLine lineNumber="92"><Highlight kind="comment">///                      Instrumenting inline assembly.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00093" /><CodeLine lineNumber="93"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00094" /><CodeLine lineNumber="94"><Highlight kind="comment">/// For inline assembly code LLVM has little idea about which memory locations</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00095" /><CodeLine lineNumber="95"><Highlight kind="comment">/// become initialized depending on the arguments. It can be possible to figure</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00096" /><CodeLine lineNumber="96"><Highlight kind="comment">/// out which arguments are meant to point to inputs and outputs, but the</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00097" /><CodeLine lineNumber="97"><Highlight kind="comment">/// actual semantics can be only visible at runtime. In the Linux kernel it&#39;s</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00098" /><CodeLine lineNumber="98"><Highlight kind="comment">/// also possible that the arguments only indicate the offset for a base taken</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00099" /><CodeLine lineNumber="99"><Highlight kind="comment">/// from a segment register, so it&#39;s dangerous to treat any asm() arguments as</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00100" /><CodeLine lineNumber="100"><Highlight kind="comment">/// pointers. We take a conservative approach generating calls to</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00101" /><CodeLine lineNumber="101"><Highlight kind="comment">///   &#95;&#95;msan&#95;instrument&#95;asm&#95;store(ptr, size)</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00102" /><CodeLine lineNumber="102"><Highlight kind="comment">/// , which defer the memory unpoisoning to the runtime library.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00103" /><CodeLine lineNumber="103"><Highlight kind="comment">/// The latter can perform more complex address checks to figure out whether</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00104" /><CodeLine lineNumber="104"><Highlight kind="comment">/// it&#39;s safe to touch the shadow memory.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00105" /><CodeLine lineNumber="105"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Like with atomic operations, we call &#95;&#95;msan&#95;instrument&#95;asm&#95;store() before</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00106" /><CodeLine lineNumber="106"><Highlight kind="comment">/// the assembly call, so that changes to the shadow memory will be seen by</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00107" /><CodeLine lineNumber="107"><Highlight kind="comment">/// other threads together with main memory initialization.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00108" /><CodeLine lineNumber="108"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00109" /><CodeLine lineNumber="109"><Highlight kind="comment">///                  KernelMemorySanitizer (KMSAN) implementation.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00110" /><CodeLine lineNumber="110"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00111" /><CodeLine lineNumber="111"><Highlight kind="comment">/// The major differences between KMSAN and MSan instrumentation are:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00112" /><CodeLine lineNumber="112"><Highlight kind="comment">///  - KMSAN always tracks the origins and implies msan-keep-going=true;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00113" /><CodeLine lineNumber="113"><Highlight kind="comment">///  - KMSAN allocates shadow and origin memory for each page separately, so</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00114" /><CodeLine lineNumber="114"><Highlight kind="comment">///    there are no explicit accesses to shadow and origin in the</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00115" /><CodeLine lineNumber="115"><Highlight kind="comment">///    instrumentation.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00116" /><CodeLine lineNumber="116"><Highlight kind="comment">///    Shadow and origin values for a particular X-byte memory location</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00117" /><CodeLine lineNumber="117"><Highlight kind="comment">///    (X=1,2,4,8) are accessed through pointers obtained via the</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00118" /><CodeLine lineNumber="118"><Highlight kind="comment">///      &#95;&#95;msan&#95;metadata&#95;ptr&#95;for&#95;load&#95;X(ptr)</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00119" /><CodeLine lineNumber="119"><Highlight kind="comment">///      &#95;&#95;msan&#95;metadata&#95;ptr&#95;for&#95;store&#95;X(ptr)</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00120" /><CodeLine lineNumber="120"><Highlight kind="comment">///    functions. The corresponding functions check that the X-byte accesses</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00121" /><CodeLine lineNumber="121"><Highlight kind="comment">///    are possible and returns the pointers to shadow and origin memory.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00122" /><CodeLine lineNumber="122"><Highlight kind="comment">///    Arbitrary sized accesses are handled with:</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00123" /><CodeLine lineNumber="123"><Highlight kind="comment">///      &#95;&#95;msan&#95;metadata&#95;ptr&#95;for&#95;load&#95;n(ptr, size)</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00124" /><CodeLine lineNumber="124"><Highlight kind="comment">///      &#95;&#95;msan&#95;metadata&#95;ptr&#95;for&#95;store&#95;n(ptr, size);</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00125" /><CodeLine lineNumber="125"><Highlight kind="comment">///    Note that the sanitizer code has to deal with how shadow/origin pairs</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00126" /><CodeLine lineNumber="126"><Highlight kind="comment">///    returned by the these functions are represented in different ABIs. In</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00127" /><CodeLine lineNumber="127"><Highlight kind="comment">///    the X86&#95;64 ABI they are returned in RDX:RAX, in PowerPC64 they are</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00128" /><CodeLine lineNumber="128"><Highlight kind="comment">///    returned in r3 and r4, and in the SystemZ ABI they are written to memory</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00129" /><CodeLine lineNumber="129"><Highlight kind="comment">///    pointed to by a hidden parameter.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00130" /><CodeLine lineNumber="130"><Highlight kind="comment">///  - TLS variables are stored in a single per-task struct. A call to a</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00131" /><CodeLine lineNumber="131"><Highlight kind="comment">///    function &#95;&#95;msan&#95;get&#95;context&#95;state() returning a pointer to that struct</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00132" /><CodeLine lineNumber="132"><Highlight kind="comment">///    is inserted into every instrumented function before the entry block;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00133" /><CodeLine lineNumber="133"><Highlight kind="comment">///  - &#95;&#95;msan&#95;warning() takes a 32-bit origin parameter;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00134" /><CodeLine lineNumber="134"><Highlight kind="comment">///  - local variables are poisoned with &#95;&#95;msan&#95;poison&#95;alloca() upon function</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00135" /><CodeLine lineNumber="135"><Highlight kind="comment">///    entry and unpoisoned with &#95;&#95;msan&#95;unpoison&#95;alloca() before leaving the</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00136" /><CodeLine lineNumber="136"><Highlight kind="comment">///    function;</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00137" /><CodeLine lineNumber="137"><Highlight kind="comment">///  - the pass doesn&#39;t declare any global variables or add global constructors</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00138" /><CodeLine lineNumber="138"><Highlight kind="comment">///    to the translation unit.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00139" /><CodeLine lineNumber="139"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00140" /><CodeLine lineNumber="140"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Also, KMSAN currently ignores uninitialized memory passed into inline asm</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00141" /><CodeLine lineNumber="141"><Highlight kind="comment">/// calls, making sure we&#39;re on the safe side wrt. possible false positives.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00142" /><CodeLine lineNumber="142"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00143" /><CodeLine lineNumber="143"><Highlight kind="comment">///  KernelMemorySanitizer only supports X86&#95;64, SystemZ and PowerPC64 at the</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00144" /><CodeLine lineNumber="144"><Highlight kind="comment">///  moment.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00145" /><CodeLine lineNumber="145"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00146" /><CodeLine lineNumber="146"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00147" /><CodeLine lineNumber="147"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// FIXME: This sanitizer does not yet handle scalable vectors</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00148" /><CodeLine lineNumber="148"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00291" /><CodeLine lineNumber="291"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// This flag makes the compiler conservatively unpoison every memory location</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00292" /><CodeLine lineNumber="292"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// passed into an assembly call. Note that this may cause false positives.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00300" /><CodeLine lineNumber="300"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// This flag controls whether we check the shadow of the address</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00301" /><CodeLine lineNumber="301"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// operand of load or store. Such bugs are very rare, since load from</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00302" /><CodeLine lineNumber="302"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// a garbage address typically results in SEGV, but still happen</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00303" /><CodeLine lineNumber="303"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// (e.g. only lower bits of address are garbage, or the access happens</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00304" /><CodeLine lineNumber="304"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// early at program startup where malloc-ed memory is more likely to</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l02455" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2455"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02456" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2456"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// This class implements the general case of shadow propagation, used in all</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02457" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2457"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// cases where we don&#39;t know and/or don&#39;t care about what the operation</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02458" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2458"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// actually does. It converts all input shadow values to a common type</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02459" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2459"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// (extending or truncating as necessary), and bitwise OR&#39;s them.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02460" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2460"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02461" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2461"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// This is much cheaper than inserting checks (i.e. requiring inputs to be</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02462" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2462"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// fully initialized), and less prone to false positives.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02463" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2463"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02464" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2464"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// This class also implements the general case of origin propagation. For a</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02465" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2465"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Nary operation, result origin is set to the origin of an argument that is</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02466" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2466"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// not entirely initialized. If there is more than one such arguments, the</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02467" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2467"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// rightmost of them is picked. It does not matter which one is picked if all</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02468" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2468"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// arguments are initialized.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l02874" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2874"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Instrument llvm.memmove</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02875" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2875"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02876" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2876"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// At this point we don&#39;t know if llvm.memmove will be inlined or not.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02877" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2877"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// If we don&#39;t instrument it and it gets inlined,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02878" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2878"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// our interceptor will not kick in and we will lose the memmove.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02879" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2879"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// If we instrument the call here, but it does not get inlined,</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02880" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2880"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// we will memove the shadow twice: which is bad in case</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02881" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2881"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// of overlapping regions. So, we simply lower the intrinsic to a call.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02882" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2882"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02883" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2883"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Similar situation exists for memcpy and memset.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02884" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2884" lineLink="/docs/api/structs/anonymous-namespace-memorysanitizer-cpp-/memorysanitizervisitor/#a5f93e75a1bd79aad5f817f9980e02cb3"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordtype">void</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/structs/anonymous-namespace-memorysanitizer-cpp-/memorysanitizervisitor/#a5f93e75a1bd79aad5f817f9980e02cb3">visitMemMoveInst</a>(<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/memmoveinst">MemMoveInst</a> &amp;<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/support/md5-cpp/#ac0eafdc9ee161b71e7af98af736952fd">I</a>) &#123;</Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l02892" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2892"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02893" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2893"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Instrument memcpy</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02894" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2894"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02895" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2895"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Similar to memmove: avoid copying shadow twice. This is somewhat</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02896" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2896"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// unfortunate as it may slowdown small constant memcpys.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02897" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2897"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// FIXME: consider doing manual inline for small constant sizes and proper</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02898" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2898"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// alignment.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02899" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2899"><Highlight kind="comment">  ///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02900" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2900"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Note: This also handles memcpy.inline, which promises no calls to external</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02901" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2901"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// functions as an optimization. However, with instrumentation enabled this</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02902" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2902"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// is difficult to promise; additionally, we know that the MSan runtime</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02903" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2903"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// exists and provides &#95;&#95;msan&#95;memcpy(). Therefore, we assume that with</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02904" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2904"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// instrumentation it&#39;s safe to turn memcpy.inline into a call to</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02905" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2905"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// &#95;&#95;msan&#95;memcpy(). Should this be wrong, such as when implementing memcpy()</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02906" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2906"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// itself, instrumentation should be disabled with the no&#95;sanitize attribute.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02907" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2907" lineLink="/docs/api/structs/anonymous-namespace-memorysanitizer-cpp-/memorysanitizervisitor/#aec582588d2e3296c8e411ebf91d528b0"><Highlight kind="normal">  </Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordtype">void</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/structs/anonymous-namespace-memorysanitizer-cpp-/memorysanitizervisitor/#aec582588d2e3296c8e411ebf91d528b0">visitMemCpyInst</a>(<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/memcpyinst">MemCpyInst</a> &amp;<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/support/md5-cpp/#ac0eafdc9ee161b71e7af98af736952fd">I</a>) &#123;</Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l04046" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4046"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Approximation only:</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04047" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4047"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//    output         = horizontal&#95;add/sub(A, B)</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04048" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4048"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// =&gt; shadow&#91;output&#93; = horizontal&#95;add(shadow&#91;A&#93;, shadow&#91;B&#93;)</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04049" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4049"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04050" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4050"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// We always use horizontal add instead of subtract, because subtracting</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04051" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4051"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// a fully uninitialized shadow would result in a fully initialized shadow.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04052" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4052"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04053" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4053"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// - If we add two adjacent zero (initialized) shadow values, the</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04054" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4054"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//   result always be zero i.e., no false positives.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04055" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4055"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// - If we add two shadows, one of which is uninitialized, the</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04056" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4056"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//   result will always be non-zero i.e., no false negatives.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04057" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4057"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// - However, we can have false negatives if we do an addition that wraps</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04058" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4058"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//   to zero; we consider this an acceptable tradeoff for performance.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04059" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4059"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04060" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4060"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// To make shadow propagation precise, we want the equivalent of</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04061" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4061"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// &quot;horizontal OR&quot;, but this is not available for SSE3/SSSE3/AVX/AVX2.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04062" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4062"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l04135" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4135"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// - st1&#95;x4 is non-interleaved e.g., st1&#95;x4 (inA, inB, inC, inD, outP)</Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l04220" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4220"><Highlight kind="comment">  /// Handle intrinsics by applying the intrinsic to the shadows.</Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l05353" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5353"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Conservative inline assembly handling: check for poisoned shadow of</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l05354" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5354"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// asm() arguments, then unpoison the result and all the memory locations</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l05355" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5355"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// pointed to by those arguments.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l05356" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5356"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// An inline asm() statement in C++ contains lists of input and output</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l05357" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5357"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// arguments used by the assembly code. These are mapped to operands of the</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l05358" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5358"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// CallInst as follows:</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l05359" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5359"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//  - nR register outputs (&quot;=r) are returned by value in a single structure</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l05360" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5360"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//  (SSA value of the CallInst);</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l05361" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5361"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//  - nO other outputs (&quot;=m&quot; and others) are returned by pointer as first</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l05362" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5362"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// nO operands of the CallInst;</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l05363" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5363"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//  - nI inputs (&quot;r&quot;, &quot;m&quot; and others) are passed to CallInst as the</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l05364" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5364"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// remaining nI operands.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l05365" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5365"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// The total number of asm() arguments in the source is nR+nO+nI, and the</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l05366" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5366"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// corresponding CallInst has nO+nI+1 operands (the last operand is the</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l05367" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5367"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// function to be called).</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l05887" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5887"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// One caveat is it requires only to propagate the non-named arguments,</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l05889" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5889"><Highlight kind="normal">      </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// saved. So to copy the shadow values from the va&#95;arg TLS array</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
